text: to walton by john keats read by nicholas shore for the babe season of mists and mellow fruitfulness close bosom friend of the maturing sun conspiring with him how to load and bless with fruit the vines that round the thatch eaves run to bend with apples than most cottage trees and fill all fruit with ripeness to the core to swell the gourd and plump the hazel shells with a sweet kernel to set budding more and still more the flowers for the bees until they think warm days will never cease for some of us old brantefields the semidiameter seeks abroad may find thee sitting careless on a granary floor thy hair soft lifted by the winnowing wind or on a half reap'd furrow sound asleep drowsed with the fume of poppies while thy hook spares the next swath and all its twined flowers and sometimes like a gleaner thou dost keep steady thy laden head across a brook or by a cider press with patient look thou wantest a last musingly wheresoever they not of that now as i made to one bare clouds bloom the soft dying day and touch the stubble plains with rosy hue then in a wailful choir the small gnats mourn in the river so onlooking as the light wind lives or dies and full grown lambs loud bleat from hilly boltsprit sin and a ouittebe soft the recess where from her garden for the gathering swallows twitter in the guise
